Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: An exploratory investigation of the impact of the Center for Diverse Leadership in Science logic model on faculty and student development

Division.LongName: Div of Res, Innovation, Synergies, & Edu

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this EAGER project is to examine the impacts of the UCLA Center for Diverse Leadership in Science (CDLS) faculty and trainee development models on ocean science education. The CDLS faculty development model aims to grow faculty skills in inclusive mentoring, inclusive teaching, and cultural awareness, and put these skills into practice. The trainee development model includes constructing learning environments to promote experiential learning, science identity, and social belonging, through team-based research, team-based outreach, and technical and higher skills development, with vertical and peer mentorship. For both faculty and trainees, CDLS builds communities of learning and practice. This project would do exploratory work to adapt and assess a new set of logic models for broadening participation in ocean sciences. It would create new curricular materials and implement them to transition a traditional theoretical undergraduate curriculum in a non-diverse department (Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences) into one that includes extracurricular field opportunities, problems-based activities, community outreach, and service learning. It will also impact teaching in two additional departments (Earth, Planetary, and Space Sciences, Environmental Science) where participants and collaborators teach. A broader aim will be to reach 200+ students/year once created, of which 25% will be from underrepresented groups. The project would support multiple trainees including undergraduates and graduate students from underrepresented groups, and an early career project scientist, as well as support partnerships with multiple high schools and youth centers in low-income minority neighborhoods, and a non-profit. Through assessment, conference presentations, and an initial manuscript on the results, the PIs will document learning gains, engagement, higher skills, persistence, and broadening participation.<br/><br/>This project will test the impact of the CDLS logic models in ocean science education, and specifically will assess the impacts of the team's approaches on growth of 1) inclusive mentoring and teaching practices, and actions that relate to enhanced cultural awareness in faculty, and 2) engagement, grades, retention, science identity, and social belonging in trainees through stated activities. This approach should increase opportunities for undergraduate students to have hands-on and meaningful learning experiences in oceanography, that also promotes inclusion and the recruitment and retention of students from underrepresented groups in the field, while at the same time supporting the persistence of graduate students and early career scientists from underrepresented groups in the field. To achieve project goals, PIs will 1) grow cultural awareness skills and practices in current and future ocean science educators, through completion of mentoring curriculum by project participants, 2) undergraduate students working in teams with project participants from underrepresented groups by 3) curriculum modification, 4) field-based experiences, 5) service-learning projects with a local non-profit, and 6) student-created public ocean science engagement projects. PIs predict the focus on using oceanographic knowledge in service to address current problems, community outreach, and experiential learning, along with the provision of team-based work and concordant role models, will support high levels of recruitment, persistence, and engagement.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this support from NSF, CDLS Oceans now supports ten faculty fellows at UCLA and CSUN, and 30 Early Career Fellows (ECFs) across three universities (primarily UCLA, but also CSUN and UCSB) and seven departments. ECFs include post-baccalaureate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers, of whom 80% are underrepresented minorities (URM), 87% people of color (POC), and 67% women, and are mentored by faculty fellows. We have further mentored 30 undergraduate students in laboratory- and field-based research. Curricula for six courses have been revised by CDLS Oceans faculty and staff. Approximately 100 students from these courses have toured research laboratory facilities with CDLS ECFs, engaged in field-based oceanography, and 500 students have taken classes with revised curriculum. Two staff members, project scientist and co-PI Jeana Drake, and CSUN graduate student Taylorann Smith, coordinate CDLS Oceans activities. To support these teaching and mentoring activities, two CDLS Ocean faculty members (PI Eagle and co-PI Tripati) and two research staff members have been trained to facilitate Entering Mentoring workshops, having participated in formal training designed by the University of Wisconsin-Madison’s Center for Improved Mentoring Experiences in Research, and have offered two mentoring workshops to date.

 

Several team-based projects have been undertaken by CDLS Oceans to support priorities identified by partners, graduate student training, and workforce development. These include environmental DNA (eDNA) sampling of salmonid migration in Mill Creek, a site culturally important to the Amah Mutsun Tribal Band (AMTB), following removal of a dam; eDNA sampling of marine seagrass, oyster bed, and kelp restoration efforts around Catalina island and along coastal Los Angeles in partnership with the Bay Foundation and Heal the Bay; proteomics and trace element geochemistry analysis of stony corals and coralline algae; and coccolithophore calcification inhibition and proteomics. Five ECFs have been trained in eDNA extraction and sequencing, qPCR, and nutrient, carbonate chemistry, and chlorophyll analyses. These projects support ECFs who identify as LGBTQIA+ and/or persons of color.

 

A central focus of the CDLS Oceans efforts has been our work with tribal partners. We have held ~30 virtual meetings with representatives of AMTB and its Land Trust (AMLT). CDLS Oceans faculty, staff, and ECFs have participated in six reciprocal site visits to tribally managed lands near Santa Cruz and to UCLA, including a Salmon Welcoming Ceremony and three talking circles. eDNA has been collected at Mill Creek five times and incorporated training AMLT Stewards in collection and sample processing. To support cultural relearning, a CDLS Oceans ECF also worked with AMLT Youth to develop cultural and conservation curricula to be shared with the tribal community. In addition to our work with AMLT, we have been collaborating with Gabrielino-Tongva tribal members at the Kuruvunga Springs Foundation to sample water quality of one of their sacred spring sites and engaged in relationship building with Northern Chumash tribal representatives to learn more about their leadership in establishing a cultural marine protected area (MPA) in Santa Barbara and San Luis Obispo counties.

 

A field-based project that has provided hands-on opportunities for multiple UCLA undergraduate students is run by two female graduate students, one of whom is a person of color. These students conduct monthly sampling at two locations - one onshore and one offshore - in the Santa Monica Bay where they collect surface and depth water samples for eDNA, nutrients, organic and inorganic particulate carbon, chlorophyll, plankton, and carbonate chemistry. To date, they have produced a dataset of 10 consecutive months’ worth of sampling. These data and comparable data from the restoration site sampling described above have been assembled and plotted in ArcGIS by a student admitted to UCLA’s Grand Challenge program to compare (1) between onshore and offshore sites, (2) through time, and (3) to storm events. Their covariation was also studied by an undergraduate student for their senior capstone research project. Over the past four years, we have built CDLS into a model of an equitable geoscience learning ecosystem while integrating community partners at all levels of teaching and mentoring. Our formal and informal surveys of ECFs continually show us that they are learning pro-social skills and feeling supported as they develop into the geoscience leaders of tomorrow. We have sought to leverage past funding to support securing long-term funding from a variety of sources, and to help support our community partners in doing so as well, in partnership with CDLS and on their own (e.g., CSUN receiving a seed grant to support a geoscience faculty fellows program; providing funds from a CDLS NSF grant to support CSUN students; writing grants to support programs at East LA Community College, Navajo Technical University, Dine College; writing grants to support AMLT, TBF).

 

The progress of our ECFs and community partners shows us that the CDLS model works to equitably train budding geoscientists.
